dtliExcerpt: Rebecca Hall gives a mesmerizing performance as the Young Woman trapped in the mechanized routine of modern life, bringing both vulnerability and steel to this expressionist masterpiece.
bwwExcerpt: The Roundabout has been on a good streak, with daring and punchy revivals of Picnic, Cyrano de Bergerac, The Big Knife, Man and Boy andLook Back in Anger (not to mention several good new plays). Machinaltakes the biggest risks, and has the greatest payoff. If you care about American theater-particularly its experimental heritage-go now. I seriously hope that the Roundabout's audiences are thrilled by what they see. But if Todd Haimes gets complaints from people who were rattled or disturbed, that only means the machine is working smoothly.

wrongFullText:
Stage and screen star Rebecca Hall stars in journalist-playwright Sophie Treadwell's 1928 classic about a woman whose attempts to escape society's gears result in madness and homicide. The revival of this rarely seen modern classic is staged by acclaimed British director Lyndsey Turner.

American Airlines Theatre
 
 227 W 42nd St
 
 
 Midtown West
 
 New York

between Seventh and Eighth Aves

Subway: A, C, E to 42nd St–Port Authority; N, Q, R, 42nd St S, 1, 2, 3, 7 to 42nd St–Times Sq

Theater. Experimental theater. Drama
